s.text: American companies investing in Puerto Rico have long been exempted from income tax, making the island a manufacturing and pharmaceutical center.
The island still receives $10 billion in assistance (including entitlements) each year.

Congress governed the Caribbean island directly as a territory until 1952, when it expanded Puerto Rican autonomy by making it a "commonwealth," allowing it to adopt a constitution and create a locally elected government with statelike powers.
Statehood advocates desire the benefits of constitutional citizenship, the federal safety net, and the economic stability that will likely follow.
In 1995, the General Accounting Office estimated statehood would cost the U.S. Treasury another $3 billion in annual benefits.
